awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Inviscid Limits and Stability at High Reynolds Numbers
awd_abstract_narration:
In many applications of fluid mechanics, such as those arising in atmosphere and ocean sciences, aerospace engineering, and high-energy or fusion plasma physics, understanding the dynamics of fluids and plasmas where dissipative forces (e.g., friction) are weak is crucial.  For example, the stability of the layer of air over a wing, and the dissipation of energy nearby, can have major implications for the aircraft, such as drastically changing the fuel efficiency.  The focus of the project is to better understand dissipation and stability of equilibrium configurations and related problems in this regime using mathematical analysis.  The project helps lay the foundation for a wider mathematical theory on mixing, dissipation, and stability in fluid mechanics.  As it requires both pure and applied mathematical innovations, it also presents an excellent opportunity to train new, versatile researchers who are fluent in both scientific applications and sophisticated mathematical analysis.    Graduate students are included in the work of the project.

The project aims to further elucidate basic questions of nonlinear stability, direct cascades, and the dissipation of enstrophy or energy at small scales in fluids and to expand the rigorous mathematical theory for understanding these phenomena.  The investigator and his collaborators focus on fundamental questions that will have broad impact due to intrinsic interest, as will the new tools developed to solve them.  Three general areas are studied: (A) analysis tools for understanding enhanced dissipation and transient unmixing; (B) linear and nonlinear stochastically forced problems in order to understand statistically stationary direct cascades in mathematically accessible settings; (C) estimating the subcritical transition thresholds and understanding instabilities for laminar flows, such as pipe flow, in infinite and finite regularity.  Finally, natural extensions to hypoelliptic problems, such as collisionless limits in kinetic theory, may also be considered.  The work is primarily mathematical analysis; however, computer experiments may be performed in order to provide preliminary insights and to provide accessible training opportunities for undergraduates in applied mathematics.  Graduate students are included in the research activities.

por.por_cntn:
In many applications of fluid mechanics, such as those arising in atmosphere and ocean sciences, aerospace engineering, and high-energy or fusion plasma physics, understanding the dynamics of fluids and plasmas where dissipative forces (e.g. friction) are weak is crucial. For example, the stability of the layer of air over a wing can have major implications for the aircraft, such as drastically changing the fuel efficiency. 

The research supported by the grant developed a variety of new mathematical ideas for understanding the dissipation and stability of special configurations and related problems in this regime using mathematical analysis. Of particular note are the works on vortex stability, both in 2d and 3d (i.e. understanding the behavior of rapidly rotating configurations of fluid, essentially idealized models for configurations such as hurricanes, tornadoes, wing-tip vortices, and other similar structures). These works provided some insight into how and why these vortex configurations are relatively stable compared to other configurations and why they behave as we observe them. 

The research also supported significant breakthroughs in understanding the behavior of fluid models subjected to random forcing. The goal here is to develop mathematical theory to describe and predict the statistics when the dissipative or internal friction forces are weak. Of particular note are the results on mixing (we obtained a mathematical understanding of how dye or chemical solutes will be stirred and diffused by the motion of the fluid), the proof of Batchelor's law (a classical prediction on the statistics of temperature or density fluctuations dating from 1959 but which lacked a mathematical justification, despite long being confirmed by natural observations and experiments), and the development of new mathematical methods for studying chaos in wide classes of high-dimensional random systems, including computer simulations of fluid equations.  

In addition to the mathematical results themselves, the grant provided excellent training for young and versatile researchers who are fluent in both scientific applications and sophisticated mathematical analysis. Three post-doctoral scholars were supported on this grant, all of whom are now tenure-track at research universities (two in the US, Georgia Institute of Technology and Tulane University, and one in England, Imperial College of London). Three UMD graduate students were supported by the grant (two are still at UMD, one is now a post-doc at Duke University). One undergraduate student worked on projects related to this grant (now a graduate student at University of Texas, Austin). Additionally, the PI gave many mini-courses and expository talks to graduate students, post-doctoral scholars, and fellow faculty within the US, Europe, and others streamed online due to the pandemic. Several works appeared for wider audiences, including articles in Quanta, Cosmos, and SIAM News.
